body: Thank  @tkonolige for the confirmation, I have regolden the test case and all of test cases are passed.
[related this pull request ](https://github.com/apache/tvm/pull/8704)

> @leandron Thanks for the review. Does this need a rebase?

I think it needs at least a force-push to re-trigger CI.

OK, so based on @areusch's approval, I'm merging this.

Thanks @Mousius and @areusch!

> But in a longer term, it might make sense to revisit Mali target design in TVM.

I agree we need to resolve the naming confusion here (though not in this PR). Probably we need to enhance the Mali target to accept an architecture argument where we can pass through Midgard/Bifrost/Valhall.

TL;DR:
if you see `No such property: ci_lint_param for class: groovy.lang.Binding`, just force-push your PR again.

----

It looks like for existing PRs, this change on the Jenkins file needs to be reloaded once in CI for each pipeline, and will need at least one re-run to make it work.

In case you see this fail with the error below, **just force-push your PR again, and the error will go away.**

```
groovy.lang.MissingPropertyException: No such property: ci_lint_param for class: groovy.lang.Binding
	at groovy.lang.Binding.getVariable(Binding.java:63)
	at org.jenkinsci.plugins.scriptsecurity.sandbox.groovy.SandboxInterceptor.onGetProperty(SandboxInterceptor.java:270)
	at org.kohsuke.groovy.sandbox.impl.Checker$7.call(Checker.java:353)
	at org.kohsuke.groovy.sandbox.impl.Checker.checkedGetProperty(Checker.java:357)
	at org.kohsuke.groovy.sandbox.impl.Checker.checkedGetProperty(Checker.java:333)
	at org.kohsuke.groovy.sandbox.impl.Checker.checkedGetProperty(Checker.java:333)
	at com.cloudbees.groovy.cps.sandbox.SandboxInvoker.getProperty(SandboxInvoker.java:29)
	at com.cloudbees.groovy.cps.impl.PropertyAccessBlock.rawGet(PropertyAccessBlock.java:20)
	at WorkflowScript.run(WorkflowScript:128)
	at ___cps.transform___(Native Method)
	at com.cloudbees.groovy.cps.impl.PropertyishBlock$ContinuationImpl.get(PropertyishBlock.java:74)
...
```
cc @tqchen @areusch for reviews. Sorry about the havoc this might create in CI, before the fix is merged.

Hi @huanmei9, just curious what the use case is here? Doesn't this allow for race conditions and pollution by re-using temporary directories?
Congrats!!
Thanks everyone!
I believe the correct way to do this is [`os.makedirs`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.makedirs) with `exist_ok=True`.
Thanks @ryujaehun @junrushao1994
The RPC server behaves nicely on a variety of devices, including the Arduino Due, Seeed Wio Terminal, and Sony Spresense. It's just the Nano 33 BLE which has this issue.
thanks @guberti !

> I've been working with the `base-box-tool` a lot on #8748, and these changes make it much clearer how to use it. Thanks @gromero!

@areusch LGTM! Although I think it won't fix totally https://github.com/apache/tvm/issues/8728 this looks correct to me and also there is a chance we will at least reduce the frequency PR 8728 happens in the CI, which is great. Thanks!
@areusch btw! the commit message cites PR 8278 (* suspect this should fix #8278) but it's indeed instead 8728! If there is still time...
thanks @gromero!
we think there are still some lingering bugs, potentially Zephyr-side though not clear now, but we suspect #8761 will address one class of these failures.
@gromero is investigating further

@jiangjiajun sorry for slowing you down, my worry was mostly about retriggering CI as there have been some CI stability issues lately and I wanted to make sure the CI changes went in since multiple PRs are blocked on that. Feel free to merge now. Sorry again. I also realized I linked the wrong PR 😅 I meant to type one that was from Erc.
Thanks Jared!
It looks good to me, and please fix the unittest: basically it says "global" != ""
Hmm I agree with @tkonolige. It is slightly better to use the existing API provided by python. Please make changes accordingly and then we get the PR merged :-) Thanks a lot!
Will review tomorrow
CC @icemelon @comaniac @yzhliu
I know there is some dependency on the relay compile engine in some other projects. Shall we slow down a little bit and wait for some consensus? Thanks a lot!
Is this still WIP? otherwise, how will this PR pass the CI?
see ci-docker-staging run: https://ci.tlcpack.ai/blue/organizations/jenkins/tvm/detail/ci-docker-staging/150/pipeline

Hi @tkonolige @junrushao1994 .
Thanks for your suggestions, I have changed the code according to your suggestions.

@csullivan I have added the unit test of opencl for erf, please take a look.
@junrushao1994 also tag for informing you the update.
@ryujaehun you should submit another pr to restore this license line.
@ZihengJiang many thanks for the feedback, see my changes and comments. I've also added many tests. Please take a look when you have a chance.
I thought there is a check in CI to prevent this
Oh sorry, i checked it now. I think the black deleted the first line automatically.
I am sort of surprised why it is not caught by CI 🤔 Anyway, good to have it back :-)
CC @eric-haibin-lin
CC @masahi @alexwong @comaniac @yzhliu

No this builds perfectly fine locally, after the last interpreter patch went in there is no longer any need for the `compile_engine.h` header. Most of the uses have been refactored away, there is a little bit of clean up in a few tests which I will follow up with.

I know there is strong dependency to compile engine in other projects, and would love to propose several actions we could take to make sure the process working properly for both parties.

1) @comaniac @icemelon would you like to provide a list of APIs that is currently in use, and we discuss how to replace with them the new TE compiler.

2) We can discuss the possibility of moving all the workflow away from compile engine on mainline, making it obsolete, but keeping the code as it is for a while. This chunk of code will be unused and untested but kept for several release cycles to make sure downstream projects are not affected. This is what we did for NNVM.

@junrushao1994 We can keep an adaptor interface for a while longer, the only challenge is at some point we are going to have to refactor the internals to handle other requirements from ARM, and other folks and so the implementation might change even if we preserve the interface. Happy to discuss more tomorrow.

@jroesch @comaniac @icemelon you guys can discuss together without me :-) I am very supportive of the new lowering process, which makes the logic much clearer, but aware of the challenges in downstream projects as well
It would be good for this scope of new feature to start with an RFC.
CC @electriclilies @ZihengJiang @jwfromm
Yeah it is super exciting feature for TVM, so would get more visibility in the community if we have like a RFC
This PR basically prevents a mutation happened in the `ToBasicBlockNormalForm` pass by shallow copying the object
Thanks @areusch !

Hi @manupa-arm,

The answer is that writing it in Python was easier for the initial version of the interface API. I agree eventually it'd be good to port it to C++ but believe it to be out of scope of this PR, it appears to be easily tested so we can guarantee it works despite it being implemented twice.
@comaniac I will follow up here: https://github.com/Xilinx/pyxir/issues/63. You can close this issue in favor of that one if you want.

Hi @bhahn221,

This is a known issue with generating C code from TVM, it defaults to trying to use vector types which aren't supported - if you add `--pass-config tir.disable_vectorize=1` to your `tvmc` command line it'll stop trying to do this and should generate valid C :smile_cat:
CC @leandron / @areusch

Hi @bhahn221. I had a look into this issue and it seems like some similar issues we've seen in past with `tvmc compile --target=c`. 

Based on the error message, it looks like we need to create a way to disable the vectorizer when using the C backend in this case? This is currently available via the `--pass-config`, *only* in `tvmc compile`.

https://github.com/apache/tvm/blob/e7748aac40bd4c263882323393ea8896837614a9/python/tvm/driver/tvmc/compiler.py#L86-L93

To do that in `tvmc tune`, my first impulse would be plumbing a similar `--pass-config` option, all the way from `tvmc tune` () to `call_all_topic_funcs` in `tvm/auto_scheduler/relay_integration.py`:

https://github.com/apache/tvm/blob/e7748aac40bd4c263882323393ea8896837614a9/python/tvm/auto_scheduler/relay_integration.py#L59-L66

I couldn't find the autotvm equivalent, on where the `PassContext` is actually called, but for now, in summary you would need to patch TVM to disable the vectorizer in the sources.

Apologies @bhahn221, I think I misunderstood the initial issue, you can add the same pass config to your python code using:
```
with tvm.transform.PassContext(opt_level=3, config={"tir.disable_vectorize": True}):
```

Ack, agree that it being out of scope.

If we agree with the direction, any thoughts on maintaining a sanitize utility only in C++ exposed to python?

@denise-k Does this impact the CI improvements you've been doing?

@areusch We had discussed moving the `docker/bash.sh` script to python for ease of maintenance.  I've started toying with tox, but I don't know if you are further along there.  If so, this would be an additional item that should be ported.
LGTM. This is dead code in-tree, appears we are uncertain about out-of-tree uses for which AFAIKT s/CompileEngine/TECompiler/g would work. Could we hot-swap in this PR?
Thanks @jtuyls, I'll close this issue here.
@leandron I am currently executing the push, will ping back when its done.

@Lunderberg thanks for opening this PR. In my opinion, it's an overall net positive to have the Vulkan tests in CI. However, until we have good data on how much run time Vulkan GPU vs. Swiftshader would add to the CI jobs, it's difficult to actually assess the impacts or vote on a decision.

For instance, if we enable Vulkan tests on the GPU and it doubles CI runtimes, we'd definitely want to assess all our options to minimize impact here, including using Swiftshader, minimizing the test cases, etc. If the test cases take 5 minutes, I'd personally have no issue landing it. But if it takes 30 mins? 1 hour? that's a bit more of a grey area for me.
@leandron its currently uploading to dockerhub
@leandron this hasn't actually tested that the image works on master, we need to wait on a `ci-staging` push before merging correct?

I'd suggest we implement the test cases and the desired behaviour here and refactor it altogether in a later PR? It'll be a bit wonky either way and we can do a single refactor to C++ rather than a hybrid using the function registry now.
After this goes green you should be gtg: https://github.com/apache/tvm/tree/ci-docker-staging

I've checked our use cases and here is my summary:
- The use of APIs such as `_CompileEngineJIT ` can be replaced directly by `te_compiler.JIT`, so it should be safe to remove them.
- You might need to work on `compile_engine.py` as well?
- I have a use case that has to be done in Python for reasons. This case use `compile_engine.get().lower(func, target)` in `compile_engine.py` to get a `CachedFunc` and then get its output TE tensors. Note that I cannot use `lower_call` in `compiler_engine.py` because I don't have the input tensors. It would be great if you're going to change this file to `te_compiler.py` with most of these API (especially `te_compiler.lower`) preserved.

This was tested in this previous job: https://ci.tlcpack.ai/blue/organizations/jenkins/tvm/detail/ci-docker-staging/146/pipeline

Is the job wrong somehow? Asking so I can do it correctly next time.
@Johnson9009 By design, we need to keep the immutability of AST instead of mutating it inplace, so I guess we should make it return a constant reference

Hey @areusch @leandron, this PR depends on a re-build of the CI image to include paddle-paddle in our unittests (https://github.com/apache/tvm/pull/8742). Do you guys know when the next rebuild is scheduled? Thanks a lot!

@junrushao1994 we now rebuild nightly to tlcpackstaging docker hub account. You can use those containers; however, you need to test them in CI first by pushing to ci-docker-staging. Feel free to do this and then, assuming the results are good, push them to tlcpack.
I guess we cannot remove `compile_engine.py` but need to rename and refactor it, because some functions there, such as `lower_call` and `select_implementation` are still used by TE compiler.
Thanks @kueitang @junrushao1994

ah--just clarifying for @jroesch. 

Jared, it's not generally true right now that the nightly build pipeline will run the built docker images through CI. @leandron is working on that.

However in this case, it appears that he has used ci-docker-staging already to test these containers, since he is a committer. You can verify that in fact he did test these images by looking at the revision in Jenkins: https://ci.tlcpack.ai/blue/organizations/jenkins/tvm/detail/ci-docker-staging/146/pipeline/52

For instance here, you can see he tested `tlcpackstaging/ci_cpu:20210815-225913-1a95f9bd0`. So that image is good to go.

In this case, his test also doubled as a test of the docker image override mechanism he built to run these tests nightly.

A slight aside: Please don't update ci-qemu. I am sabotaging our system--I rebuilt that one manually last night and not sure if the new build has not picked up the changes that are already submitted as part of ci-qemu:v0.08.

@areusch ok cool, sorry for misunderstanding here @leandron. Can we add a check box or something as part of the template process until its fully automated so I/we can figure out if we need to trigger another build?
I am going to land this one to keep the PR Q moving, thanks guys!

@mikepapadim I think this might still be busted. can you see if you can run it through a staging jenkins? [here's](https://github.com/areusch/incubator-tvm/tree/jenkinsfile_upd_test_failure) what i am using to test your change
agreed that `operator->() const` should not return a mutable pointer, wonder if this could be connected to various other similar problems we've had (e.g. AlterOpLayout).

Thanks @shingjan for the contribution! This work definitely makes Popen more complete, in terms of customizable initialization of workers :-)

BTW, please document the usage of this argument, so that users could understand what is going on under the hood
Thanks @shingjan , this will unblock refactor of using PopenPool in autotvm

BTW, if we have a file containing user-registered functions, can we send this to the worker process so that the worker is aware of these registration? I suppose it is as simple as sending an "import XXX"

> BTW, if we have a file containing user-registered functions, can we send this to the worker process so that the worker is aware of these registration? I suppose it is as simple as sending an "import XXX"

In this case the registry map need to be sent. Sending an 'import' may also work, it requires the user file that calls register_func be available in PYTHONPATH

@vinx13 this snippet does work, but i am not sure if it is the best way to do:

```python
import importlib.util
spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location("mymodule", "/home/jrshao/Projects/tvm-tensorir-dev/tests/python/tir/util.py")
foo = importlib.util.module_from_spec(spec)
spec.loader.exec_module(foo)
```

Thanks, I will write an RFC this week.

Thanks for the PR. For large scope new features, we recommend to file an RFC first to propose the motivation, approach and interfaces to the community for discussions. Please see the guideline here: https://github.com/apache/tvm-rfcs
That is completed now. Closing the issue. Thanks @jroesch.
Yeah we find it super exciting and happy to discuss more with the RFC process
